content: In a room, there are 4 cats. Each cat is sitting in one corner of the square-shaped room and facing the center. They all start walking at the same time towards the cat they see directly across from them. How many times do the cats cross paths?

Now, each cat starts walking towards the cat directly across from them. So, cat A would walk towards cat C, and cat B towards cat D, assuming that across means opposite corners.

Wait a minute, in a square, opposite corners are diagonally across from each other. So, if cat A is at one corner, cat C is at the opposite corner, and similarly, cat B is opposite cat D.

So, if they all start walking towards their opposite cat, their paths would be along the diagonals of the square.

In that case, since they're all moving towards their opposite at the same time, they would all move along the diagonals towards each other.

Now, in a square, the two diagonals intersect at the center point. So, if cats A and C are walking towards each other along one diagonal, and cats B and D are walking towards each other along the other diagonal, they would all meet at the center.

But the question is, how many times do their paths cross?

Well, since they're all moving directly towards each other along straight lines, their paths would only cross once, at the center of the square.

Wait, but actually, their paths cross at the center, but do they cross each other's paths multiple times?

If they continue moving beyond the center, towards their original target, then cats A and C would pass each other at the center and continue to where cat C and A were starting, respectively.

Similarly, cats B and D would do the same.

But in that case, do their paths cross again?

Well, their paths are straight lines along the diagonals, so they only cross once, at the center.

Even if they continue moving beyond the center, their paths don't cross again because the straight lines don't intersect again.

So, overall, they only cross paths once, at the center.
